# Question 4

## Q4.1

```
>> C = rand(6,6);
>> C = C./sum(C);
>> [U, D] = eig(C)

U =

  Columns 1 through 2

  0.461039412392660 + 0.000000000000000i  0.447519540535244 + 0.235695007378730i

```

This is an example of eigenvalues that have imaginary components.

$d_{2,2}$ in matrix D

Thus it is a counterexample that all eigenvalues are real.

As number n increases, we tend to get more eigenvalues that have imaginary components, since it becomes harder to find nice eigenvalues that satisfy the condition.

## Q4.2

```
>> E = rand(5,5);
E = E./sum(E);
>> [U,D] = eig(E)

U =

  Columns 1 through 2

  0.356754735166595 + 0.000000000000000i -0.602386904104686 + 0.000000000000000i
```

This is an example of eigenvalues that have negative real components.

$d_{3,3}$ in matrix D

## Q4.3

```
>> F = rand(7,7);
F = F./sum(F);
[U,D] = eig(F)

```

From all example eigenvalue orthogonal matrices D, the largest absolute value found is 1 (real)

Usually in position $d_{1,1}$

This makes sense because the sum is always at most 1.
